page.title: West Virginia Healthy Lifestyles Act of 2005

revision.comment: Successfully de-orphaned! Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]
revision.text:
The '''West Virginia Healthy Lifestyles Act of 2005''' is a [[West Virginia]] state law enacted in 2005. Signed into law by [[Governor of West Virginia|Governor]] [[Joe Manchin III]], the act's purpose was to address [[obesity]] in the state.<ref name="rwjf">Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, "[http://www.rwjf.org/pr/product.jsp?id=38673 West Virginia Lifestyles Act of 2005 Evaluation: A Project of Information for Action: School Policies to Prevent Childhood Obesity] (February 10, 2009).</ref> The [[West Virginia Legislature|state legislature]] found in 2005 that "[[obesity epidemic|obesity is a problem of epidemic proportions]]" in West Virginia.<ref name="House Bill 2816">[http://wvde.state.wv.us/healthyschools/section6/HouseBill2816.htm House Bill 2816], West Virginia Department of Education.</ref>
[[File:JoeManchin.jpg|thumb |160px |[[Joe Manchin]] (D), then governor of West Virginia]]
==Provisions== Introduced as '''House Bill 2816''', the West Virginia Health Lifestyles Act consists of five school-based mandates which require health education assessments, fitness assessments, [[physical education]], [[body mass index]] (BMI) assessments and the availability of healthy beverages in schools.<ref name="cdc">[https://www.cdc.gov/obesity/stateprograms/fundedstates/west_virginia.html Obesity and Overweight for Professionals: State Programs: Funded States: West Virginia], Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.</ref>
The law restricts elementary schools, middle schools, and junior high schools from selling [[soft drink]]s in areas accessible to students during the school day. High schools are allowed to sell soft drinks in [[vending machine]]s during the school day only if they also offer healthy drink options as well and only if at least fifty percent of the drinks available are considered to be healthy. The law recognizes healthy drinks as water, low-fat [[milk]], [[juice]]s made one hundred percent from fruits and vegetables, and other juice drinks with a minimum of twenty percent real juice. This portion of the law states that, "Seventy-five percent of the profits from the sale of healthy beverages and soft drinks shall be allocated by a majority vote of the [[faculty senate]] of each school and twenty-five percent of the profits from the sale of healthy beverages and soft drinks shall be allocated to the purchase of necessary supplies by the principal of the school."<ref name="House Bill 2816"/>
In addition to the school-based mandates, the act created the Office of Healthy Lifestyles within the West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources, a partnership to encourage healthy lifestyles by children and families in the state, and an interest bearing account known as the Healthy Lifestyles Fund.<ref name="House Bill 2816"/>
==Implementation and funding== The policy's school-based elements were implemented beginning in 2006.<ref name="rwjf" /> The state has received funding to evaluate the legislation and its impact from the [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]], a national philanthropy organization dedicating to improving health care in the United States.<ref name="cdc" />
Carole Harris, professor of Behavioral Medicine and Psychiatry at the [[West Virginia University]], conducted research that evaluated the West Virginia Healthy Lifestyles Act and the [[West Virginia Board of Education]]’s school nutrition standards. Dr. Harris noted that participation by students and schools in health education and fitness testing had improved, but approximately 40 percent of schools are unable to meet one or more of the five mandates in the act: "The combination of these policies for nutrition and physical activity make West Virginia one of the most progressive states in the country when it comes to addressing childhood obesity and related issues. But some schools continue to struggle to provide the mandated physical education because of inadequate staffing, facilities, or both."<ref>[http://wvutoday.wvu.edu/n/2010/02/23/wvu-research-finds-healthy-lifestyles-act-and-state-nutrition-standards-help-children WVU research finds Healthy Lifestyles Act and state nutrition standards help children] (press release) (February 23, 2010). West Virginia University.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:2005 in law]] [[Category:Government of West Virginia]] [[Category:Health in West Virginia]] [[Category:Education in West Virginia]] [[Category:Obesity in the United States]] [[Category:Public health education]]

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=pt|otherarticle=Aqueduto das Águas Livres|date=December 2012}} {{tone|date=February 2017}} [[Image:Aqueduto das Águas Livres (1).jpg|200px|thumb|right|Aqueduct arches (65 m tall) over the Alcantara valley. Note the pointed shape of the arches.]] [[Image:Aqueduto das águas livres.JPG|200px|thumb|right|Aqueduct and commemorative arch in the Amoreiras neighbourhood.]] [[Image:Aqueduto das Águas Livres 2.jpg|200px|thumb|right|The aqueduct seen from the west]] The '''Águas Livres Aqueduct''' ({{lang-pt|Aqueduto das Águas Livres}}, {{IPA-pt|ɐkɨˈdutu dɐʃ ˈaɡwɐʃ ˈlivɾɨʃ|pron}}, "Aqueduct of the Free Waters") is a historic [[aqueduct (watercourse)|aqueduct]] in the city of [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]]. It is one of the most remarkable examples of 18th-century Portuguese [[engineering]]. The main course of the aqueduct covers 18 km, but the whole network of canals extends through nearly 58 km.
The city of Lisbon has always suffered from the lack of [[drinking water]], and [[John V of Portugal|King John V]] decided to build an aqueduct to bring water from sources in the [[Freguesia|parish]] of [[Caneças]], in the modern municipality of [[Odivelas]]. The project was paid for by a special [[sales tax]] on [[beef]], [[olive oil]], [[wine]], and other products.
==History== Construction started in 1731 under the direction of [[Architecture of Italy|Italian architect]] [[Antonio Canevari]], replaced in 1732 by a group of Portuguese architects and engineers, including [[Manuel da Maia]], Azevedo Fortes and [[José da Silva Pais]]. Between 1733 and 1736, the project was directed by Manuel da Maia, who in turn was replaced by Custódio Vieira, who would remain at the head of the project until around 1747.
Custódio Vieira conceived the centerpiece of the aqueduct, the arches over the Alcantara valley, completed in 1744. A total of 35 arches cross the valley, covering 941 m. The tallest arches reach a height of 65 m, and many are pointed, reminiscent of arches in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic style]]. It is considered a masterpiece of engineering in the [[Baroque]] period.
In 1748, although the project was still unfinished, the aqueduct finally started to bring water to the city of Lisbon, a fact celebrated in a commemorative arch built in the Amoreiras neighbourhood. From this period on, construction was overseen by other architects, including [[Carlos Mardel]] of [[Hungary]] and others. During the reigns of [[José I of Portugal|José I]] and [[Maria I of Portugal|Maria I]], the network of [[canal]]s and [[fountain]]s was greatly enlarged.
On November 1st, 1755, the [[1755 Lisbon earthquake]] hit the city, but the brand new aqueduct managed to remain intact.
It is possible to visit and cross the aqueduct, starting at the ''Museu da Água'' (Water Museum).
==Mãe d'Água== The ''Mãe d'Água'' (Mother of the Water) [[reservoir]] of the Amoreiras, the largest of the water reservoirs, was finished in 1834. This reservoir, with a capacity of 5,500 m³ of water, was designed by [[Carlos Mardel]]. It is now deactivated and can be visited as part of the ''Museu da Água'' (Water Museum).
== Bibliography == *{{cite book |last= [[Józef Karol Konrad Chełmicki|Chelmicki]]|first= José Carlos Conrado de|date=2008 |title= Memória sobre o Aqueducto Geral de Lisboa feita por ordem do Ministério das Obras Públicas em portaria de 15 de Fevereiro de 1856 |url= |language=Portuguese|location=Lisbon |publisher=EPAL - Empresa Portuguesa das Águas Livres |page=44 |isbn=9789899576100 |accessdate= }}
==External links== {{Commons|Aqueduto das Águas Livres}} *{{en icon}} [http://www.epal.pt/EPAL/en/menu/water-museum/useful-information/contacts-and-opening-hours The Water Museum] *{{en icon}} [http://www.igespar.pt/en/ Portuguese Institute for Architectural Heritage] *{{pt icon}} [http://www.monumentos.pt General Bureau for National Buildings and Monuments] *{{pt icon}} [http://museudaagua.epal.pt/museudaagua/index.htm Virtual visit to the Water Museum] *{{pt icon}} [http://museudaagua.blogspot.com/ The Water Museum]
